title.narrative: Anglican Council in Malawi NetsforLife Project

description.narrative: Distribute 1.2 million Long Lasting Insecticidal Nets in all the project sites in Northern Malawi, Southern Malawi, Upper Shire and Lake Malawi,Brief 398 community volunteers, 104 community leaders and 21 health workers in project sites in Northern Malawi, Southern Malawi, Lake Malawi and Upper Shire on net distribution ,Sensitize/educate 2.4 million beneficiaries on the correct and consistent use of LLINs,Support logistics for LLIN distribution in Northern, Southern & Lake Malawi and Upper Shire,Conduct door to door visits in project sites in Northern, Southern & Lake Malawi and Upper Shire to follow up on the distributed nets and promote usage by beneficiaries,Organize two drama shows each month in each of the project sites in the four dioceses,Conduct meeting with 1,400 PLWHAs on promotion of kitchen garden at household level and to discuss/sensitize them on malaria and its prevention,Commemorate World Malaria day in Nkhotakota in the Diocese of Lake Malawi, SADC Malaria week in Zomba in Diocese of Upper Shire, Child health day in Mzuzu in Diocese of Northern Malawi and Africa child day in Chikwawa in Diocese of Southern Malawi,Organize door to door visits in communities in Northern, Southern & Lake Malawi and Upper Shire on malaria prevention, treatment and case management,Introduce clean village and school competition in all the project sites in the four dioceses (Northern, Southern, Lake Malawi and Upper Shire) to promote sanitation ,Organize advocacy sessions with about 30 people consisting of village heads, staff from CHAM health facilities, religious leaders and other gatekeepers ,Identify and use role models in communities (10 role models in each of the four dioceses - Southern, Northern, Lake Malawi and Upper Shire) on malaria prevention, treatment and case management,Organize eight (8) awareness meetings per month in each project site on malaria prevention, treatment and case management ,Organize health talks in schools and health centres ,Organize monthly planning and review meetings in all project sites in Northern, Southern, Lake Malawi and Upper Shire for community leaders and volunteers at community level,Organize quarterly project visit to health workers , volunteers and club patrons in all project sites in the four dioceses for technical support and motivation,Organize quarterly District Executive Committee meetings to share project updates ,Conduct planning and review meeting with volunteers, CHAM health workers to review project progress,Organize quarterly planning and review meetings with Diocesan project staff to review project activities and finances ,Organize quarterly supervisory visit to Dioceses for technical support and motivation.,Conduct Project Evaluation ,Train 10 project staff and health workers on Integrated Community Case Management (iCCM) and Social & Behaviour Change Communication,Train ten (10) project staff in project financial management,Train 394 community volunteers on ICCM and micro credit as incentive for self-reliance

In the past six years, remarkable efforts on malaria control have led to the reduction of malaria cases in the operation areas of Anglican Council in Malawi. The Council is committed to playing a significant role in improving the health of communities through: • Mobilizing communities, to become the front line in the fight against malaria through traditional dances, drama, school club competitions and malaria open days. Community mobilization has been used as advocacy initiative aimed at generating greater awareness • Building capacity for project coordinators, health workers, and volunteers to create behavioral change interventions that encourage sleeping under treated bed nets and seeking malaria treatment promptly. • Distribution of Long Lasting Insecticidal Nets (LLINs) to households which has greatly contributed to reduction of malaria cases in the operational areas • Engaging stakeholders and community influential leaders to facilitate community ownership. The initiative has promoted a community response to tackle malaria in the four dioceses of Anglican Council in Malawi through partnership with communities, National Malaria Control Program, health workers, peer educators and other stakeholders. About 774,034 LLINs have been distributed since the inception of the program and 5,961 Malaria Control Agents trained to sensitize LLIN beneficiaries and ensure the consistent correct use of the nets.
